articles.headline: Dropping Health Plans, to Pick Better Coverage
articles.snippet: The choices offered by the Affordable Care Act are leading some small companies, which don’t have to offer health benefits, to drop their employee plans.
articles.abstract: The choices offered by the Affordable Care Act are leading some small companies, which don’t have to offer health benefits, to drop their employee plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, Keith Perkins offered health insurance to employees of his small electrical contracting company in Greencastle, Pa., and footed most of the bill. This year, with the arrival of the Affordable Care Act’s insurance marketplace, he decided to stop.

articles.headline: U.S. Suspends Nonlethal Aid to Syria Rebels
articles.snippet: The decision, just a month before a peace conference that will seek an end to the grinding civil war in Syria, demonstrated again the frustrations of trying to cultivate a viable alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The decision, just a month before a peace conference that will seek an end to the grinding civil war in Syria, demonstrated again the frustrations of trying to cultivate a viable alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just a month before a peace conference that will seek an end to the grinding civil war in Syria, the Obama administration’s decision to suspend the delivery of nonlethal aid to the moderate opposition demonstrated again the frustrations of trying to cultivate a viable alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Mark Landler and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Keep an Eye on Children, or Other Valuables
articles.snippet: Dropcam has a robust new model of its baby monitor, with features like infrared, two-way audio, an HD video-recording webcam, and motion detection.
articles.abstract: Dropcam has a robust new model of its baby monitor, with features like infrared, two-way audio, an HD video-recording webcam, and motion detection.
articles.lead_paragraph: I still remember the baby monitor my parents had — my friends and I used it as a primitive walkie-talkie.

articles.headline: For No. 2 at Fed, White House Favors Central Banker in the Bernanke Mold
articles.snippet: The administration’s interest in Stanley Fischer appears to reflect a desire for continuity at the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: The administration’s interest in Stanley Fischer appears to reflect a desire for continuity at the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stanley Fischer, the former governor of the Bank of Israel and a mentor to the Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is the leading candidate to become vice chairman of the Fed, according to former and current administration officials.

articles.headline: Accused of Harming Bees, Bayer Researches a Different Culprit
articles.snippet: The maker of a pesticide linked to the die-off of honey bees sees a different threat — varroa mites — and is working to find a remedy.
articles.abstract: The maker of a pesticide linked to the die-off of honey bees sees a different threat — varroa mites — and is working to find a remedy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONHEIM, Germany — Bayer cares about the bees.

articles.headline: Pepsi Deal Underscores an Emphasis on Snacks
articles.snippet: PepsiCo has won the business of Buffalo Wild Wings. The two plan new menu items combining products from both companies.
articles.abstract: PepsiCo has won the business of Buffalo Wild Wings. The two plan new menu items combining products from both companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusual deal that goes far beyond the soda wars, PepsiCo is to announce on Thursday that it is unseating Coca-Cola as the beverage supplier to one of the nation’s hottest restaurant chains, Buffalo Wild Wings.

articles.headline: Criminal Action Is Expected for JPMorgan in Madoff Case
articles.snippet: Federal authorities and JPMorgan Chase are expected to settle charges over ties to Bernard L. Madoff, who operated a billion-dollar Ponzi scheme using an account at the bank.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities and JPMorgan Chase are expected to settle charges over ties to Bernard L. Madoff, who operated a billion-dollar Ponzi scheme using an account at the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and federal authorities are nearing settlements over the bank’s ties to Bernard L. Madoff, striking tentative deals that would involve roughly $2 billion in penalties and a rare criminal action. The government will use a sizable portion of the money to compensate Mr. Madoff’s victims.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Tempers Flare as New Rules Strain Senate
articles.snippet: Senators on Friday headed into their third day of confirmation votes, after a second straight all-night session, the Democrats’ way of retaliating for Republican delay tactics.
articles.abstract: Senators on Friday headed into their third day of confirmation votes, after a second straight all-night session, the Democrats’ way of retaliating for Republican delay tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there is a rock bottom in the frayed relationship between Senate Republicans and Democrats, it seemed uncomfortably close as the final days of 2013 on Capitol Hill degenerated into something like an endurance contest to see who could be the most spiteful.

articles.headline: Instagram Direct Takes Photo-Sharing Private
articles.snippet: Instagram Direct would let users send private photos and videos to their friends.
articles.abstract: Instagram Direct would let users send private photos and videos to their friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Instant messaging may sound like a relic from the days of dial-up modems and AOL chat rooms.
